title: R42621
content: Facing pressure to reduce the federal budget deficit, some in the 112th Congress saw international affairs spending, including foreign aid programs, as expendable. However, others believed a strong foreign affairs budget was crucial for national security and foreign policy interests. Congress delayed passing appropriations bills, including State-Foreign Operations, until after the new fiscal year and fall elections. A continuing resolution was passed to fund the government until March 27, 2013, with the House later passing legislation (H.R. 933) on March 6, 2013. The House passed legislation (H.R. 933) on March 6, 2013, to fund federal programs for the remainder of FY2013. The Senate approved an expanded version on March 20, 2013, and the House adopted it the next day. The legislation was signed into law on March 26, 2013 (P.L. 113-6), supporting international affairs programs and activities. The State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill funds Agency for International Development (USAID) operations, public diplomacy, and international broadcasting programs. It does not align perfectly with the international affairs budget as some programs are funded through other appropriations bills. The report provides a chart illustrating the organizational structure of the bill and abbreviations of terms used. It focuses on accounts funded through the bill and provides appropriations figures for the entire international affairs budget. Congress had previously approved two OCP adjustments, reducing the pay differential by nearly 70%. The FY2013 request sought to bring the comparability pay level to match the Washington, DC, locality pay rate. Foreign aid and diplomatic programs have evolved from anti-communist focus during the Cold War to include promoting economic development, trade, education, health care, human rights, and environmental protection. Post-Cold War objectives now include nuclear non-proliferation, drug trafficking prevention, peace efforts in the Middle East, regional stability, religious freedom, and more. After the Cold War, U.S. foreign policy shifted towards new objectives such as nuclear non-proliferation, counterterrorism efforts, and global development as a pillar of national security.
